results.title: The Business of strangers [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Patrick Stettner, Robert H Nathan, Susan A Stover, i5 Films and Headquarters
results.brief_description: Patrick Stettner’s debut feature, touted as the female anti-dote to “In the company of men” (Neil LaBute, 1997), examines the politics and frissons that arise between two women of different age and class, over the course of one eventful evening. Julie Styron (Stockard Channing) is an astute vice president who, having forfeited intimate relationships, has achieved great success in her career. Panicked by an unexpected call from her boss, she calls on head-hunter Nick Harris (Frederick Weller) fishing for clues. When Paula Murphy (Julia Stiles), a temp who is hired to assist Julie with an important presentation, shows up late, Julie vents her frustration by instantaneously firing her. Later that evening, feeling faintly repentant, Julie buys Paula a drink in the hotel bar, which leads to debauchery. Despite Julie’s reluctance, Nick joins them, forming an instant attraction to Paula, and from there the film takes a dramatic turn as Nick is drugged (by Paula) and the women conspire to exact revenge upon his prone body. Despite being linked by gender and the shared experience of operating within a patriarchy, money, knowledge and age divide these women, making them, at times, adversarial. The power plays between the two make for engrossing viewing; when Paula and Julie clash, they are operating from such different spectrums that they present a fascinating interplay of agendas and morality.

results.title: Full circle
results.creator_credit: Donna Read and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Women and spirituality”.
This is a stirring documentary that awakens memories of ancestral roots that connect us to each other and to all living things. It is a journey that looks at some of the manifestations of the modern women’s spirituality movement in the western world. Through contmporary spirituality, whether from Wicca, pagan or indigenous peoples we see people communing with each other or alone. Rituals become gateways that lead to an inner place where twentieth century notions of domination over the earth are replaced with a sense of awe.

results.title: The Business of photography
results.creator_credit: K Lynch, Sally Lynch and Media West
results.brief_description: Whether you’re already a working pro or just beginning to think about a career in photography, this video is for you. You’ll meet the art directors and the editors who actually buy pictures and give out the profitable assignments. This video contains three half-hour episodes for easy viewing, the topics include preparing your portfolio, choosing your direction, formats, editing your work, selling your services, how the business works, breaking in, digging deeper, pricing and billing

results.title: Goddess remembered
results.creator_credit: Donna Read, Magaret Pettigrew and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Women and spirituality”.
This stunning and poetic documentary is a salute to 35,000 years of pre-history, to the solid values of ancestors only recently remembered, and to our ancient goddess-worshipping religions. Archaeologists and anthropologists are beginning to discover evidence of a widespread early civilisation based primarily on human co-operation. This epsiode reveals these forgotten cultures - taking us from ancient caves in France to the sun-drenched palaces at Delphi and Crete. There is also a discussion among well-known scholars such as Merlin Stone and Jean Bolen, who propose a return to a belief in an interconnected life system, with respect for the earth and the female.

results.title: The Burning times
results.creator_credit: Donna Read, Signe Johansson, Margaret Pettigrew, Mary Armstrong and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Women and spirituality”.
This beautifully crafted documentary is an in-depth look at the witch persecutions that swept through Europe just a few hundred years ago. False accusations and trials led to extensive torture and burnings at the stake, and ultimatley to the destruction of a way of life that had endured for thousands of years. Of those killed, 85% were women and widespread violence against women, still prevalent today, can be traced back to those times. It investigates the role of the Catholic Church in the crimes and explores the process whereby the old pagan communities, founded on spirituality and cooperation, were transformed into the misogynist capitalist societies of our own century.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Donna Read, Signe Johansson, Margaret Pettigrew, Mary Armstrong and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: The Business of aging
results.creator_credit: Laszlo Barna, Fred Tabachnick, Adam Symansky, Randy Sykes, Dennis McGann and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: This timely film raises the question of who should be entrusted with the care of the elderly and chronically ill—government-run or privately owned nursing homes. The Business of Aging looks into the quality of nursing home care in Canada and presents a sobering picture of residents caught in the financial squeeze as operators attempt to cut overheads at the expense of their patients.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Laszlo Barna, Fred Tabachnick, Adam Symansky, Randy Sykes, Dennis McGann and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: Iraq: cradle of civilisation
results.creator_credit: Peter Spry-Leverton, Central Productions, Nihon Hoso Kyokai, Maryland Public Television and ITV
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Legacy”.
Filmed just before and just after the Gulf War, the first program in this series looks at the effects of “civilisation” on the landscape, and the rise and fall of civilisations, particularly in relation to Iraq where civilisation began. The first cities were built 5000 years ago on the banks of the Euphrates in Southern Iraq, and city life soon transformed the human race with the glorious cultures of Mesopotamia such as Ur, Nineveh and Babylon. Michael Woods explores these ancient cultures and the legacy they gave to the history of Iraq right up to the Gulf War. The program is presented in two parts.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Peter Spry-Leverton, Central Productions, Nihon Hoso Kyokai, Maryland Public Television and ITV

results.title: The Burden of time
results.creator_credit: Peter Spry-Leverton, Nihon Hoso Kyokai, Maryland Public Television, Central Productions and ITV
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “Legacy”.
Central American civilisation developed quite independently from those of the rest of the world, yet bears striking resemblances to other great civilisations, from the great pyramids it built, and the invention of writing to the relationship of man, earth and the heavens, expressed in ritual and “the mathematics of eternity”. In spite of the disastrous past 500 years of history, the descendants of the Maya and the Aztecs have kept faith with their burden of time, through their shamen, and their blend of Christianity and the old religions, in spite of the pressures of western consumer society.
